item.title: Cli morphing changed?
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
brilliantjeana:

But it’s not simply just tor, it’s also the sdwdate and many other little things that in combine bring lots of issues.

You can use dummy-dependency to remove those too.

brilliantjeana:

So if I do wanna remove it - there’s simply no way to do it(with keeping up with updates etc)???

Not a simple way, but as explained above there is a way. dummy-dependency can be used to remove anything even if other packages depend on it. Anything you consider unnecessary, you can remove, including tor, sdwdate, etc. It might cause other things that depend on a remove component to malfunction, but if that occurs, you can reinstall the component in question (or uninstall the malfunctioning components). For instance, removing sdwdate will cause issues with sdwdate-gui, but you can remove sdwdate-gui too.

There have been requests to create a minimal variant of Kicksecure, but the demand isn’t high enough for us to commit to maintaining it (it would likely entail at least another seven images to support, maybe more).

item.title: Cli morphing changed?
item.dc:creator: @brilliantjeana
item.description:
But it’s not simply just tor, it’s also the sdwdate and many other little things that in combine bring lots of issues. I mean, if it’s a main system there would be no issue, but I’m running multiple qubes and the the resources are limited.
There are many situations where tor simply not needed at all for me, not its related things. Obviously I have kicksecure template with tor as well.

So if I do wanna remove it - there’s simply no way to do it(with keeping up with updates etc)???

item.title: Cli morphing changed?
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
If you really want to get rid of Tor, you should not apt purge it. Use dummy-dependency to remove it instead:

sudo dummy-dependency --purge --yes tor

That will remove Tor without removing kicksecure-qubes-server. Once that command is run, you should run sudo apt install kicksecure-qubes-server to ensure that software updates continue working in the future.

brilliantjeana:

So, then when -server package is being deleted I still keep all of the rest security/privacy benefits that kicksecure provides - correct?

Unfortunately no, since sometimes new security enhancements require the installation of new packages, and without kicksecure-qubes-server, those might not get installed automatically. The workaround above will let you keep the metapackage without keeping Tor.

item.title: Cli morphing changed?
item.dc:creator: @brilliantjeana
item.description:
Yes, I actually recall something like that from previous discussions/questions.
So if I don’t wanna use sdwdate and I use updates without the tor+, then I do may use purge tor and still benefit from the rest of the kicksecure security/privacy features - please confirm this if this is correct.

So, then when -server package is being deleted I still keep all of the rest security/privacy benefits that kicksecure provides - correct?

item.title: Cli morphing changed?
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
arraybolt3:
  • Kicksecure can be used with clearnet. Anonymity features are not intended to land in Kicksecure for the most part, those are for Whonix. Any time you use your web browser or most network-connected applications, they will go over clearnet.

Yes. Elaborated here:

Kicksecure – 12 Dec 25

Privacy Goals and Non-Goals of Kicksecure

An overview of the privacy goals and non-goals of Kicksecure, emphasizing its focus on security over privacy and anonymity.

brilliantjeana:

How do I use kicksecure without Tor then?

See link in my previous post.

brilliantjeana:

Why the heck then in the docs it gives a clear impression that kicksecure can be used with clearnet then???

It is possible. Because Kicksecure is based on Debian and there No Intentional User Freedom Restrictions. Hence, Kicksecure can be reconfigured.

item.title: Cli morphing changed?
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
There’s a slight misunderstanding here I think.

  • Kicksecure can be used with clearnet. Anonymity features are not intended to land in Kicksecure for the most part, those are for Whonix. Any time you use your web browser or most network-connected applications, they will go over clearnet.
  • There is a specific subset of Kicksecure features that require Tor for non-anonymity purposes. One of those is the time synchronization daemon (sdwdate, which acts as an alternative to ntpd). Another one is software updates (though this is only applicable to non-Qubes platforms).
    • sdwdate works on Qubes OS. It requires Tor because Tor provides an encrypted, authenticated way to get time values from web servers and use those to synchronize the VM’s time. Traditional methods of time synchronization (ntp) are unencrypted and vulnerable to MITM attacks, and an MITM in time synchronization can allow circumventing SSL (i.e. breaking HTTPS encryption) in some situations.
    • On non-Qubes platforms, software updates in apt are also downloaded over Tor. This is arguably an anonymity feature, but it’s for a security reason; downloading software updates over clearnet allows a malicious update server to target you (or a group you’re in) for malware while delivering uninfected software updates to others. By downloading updates over Tor, a malicious update server would have to attack everyone on the Tor network to deliver malware to you, there isn’t a good way to single you out for the bad updates.
      • Under Qubes OS this usually isn’t done by default because software updates are downloaded via an update proxy VM. If you set your Kicksecure template’s update proxy to sys-whonix, you’ll get torified software updates, otherwise software updates will be downloaded via clearnet. If you use a Kicksecure StandaloneVM, its software updates will be torified because it will connect to the Internet directly to get its updates rather than using an updates proxy.
  • Because of these specific Tor-powered features, Tor is a semi-mandatory part of Kicksecure. (edit: changed “mandatory” to “semi-mandatory” since it is important and usually shouldn’t be removed, but some users have reasons to remove it anyway.)
  • This does not mean your network traffic typically goes over Tor.

item.title: Cli morphing changed?
item.dc:creator: @brilliantjeana
item.description: I really don’t get it. Why the heck then in the docs it gives a clear impression that kicksecure can be used with clearnet then???

item.title: Cli morphing changed?
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
Yes. Tor has always been an essential part of Kicksecure, and removing it, even if it seems to work, will reduce the security of the system.

brilliantjeana:

the -cli is still present though.

The -cli metapackages are part of Kicksecure’s metapackage system but are not primary metapackages. They depend on bits of Kicksecure that are shared between both “server” and GUI installations. Having them installed is not enough to ensure updates always work. More details on how the metapackages in Kicksecure 18 work is at:

Kicksecure – 12 Dec 25

Dev/Metapackages

Development Notes / Design Documentation about Kicksecure Metapackages

item.title: Cli morphing changed?
item.dc:creator: @brilliantjeana
item.description: How do I use kicksecure without Tor then? I remember some time ago(maybe a year or a two, not sure) you said it was ok to purge tor and I used it like that. Was that wrong then???

item.title: Cli morphing changed?
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
brilliantjeana:

I used sudo apt install --no-install-recommends kicksecure-qubes-server and after completion - sudo apt purge tor -y and it deleted the kicksecure-qubes-server

please clarify. I don’t recall the same behavior with clipackage on prev version

This has unfortunately always been the case. Full user documentation and technical background:

Kicksecure – 14 Dec 25

Debian Packages

Which Kicksecure Debian packages are safe to remove? What is a meta package? What other packages do Kicksecure meta packages install? Which packages should never be removed?

For information on the removal of the tor package on Kicksecure specifically, see:

Kicksecure – 24 Dec 25

Kicksecure Tor Integration

Using Kicksecure without Tor. Can Kicksecure be used without Tor?

item.title: Cli morphing changed?
item.dc:creator: @brilliantjeana
item.description:
Even after the-serverpackage is removed, the -cli is still present though.

The thing is, I want to use kicksecure without tor. And previously there was no issue with that. Why is this all of a sudden the case? Why the heck is -server package removed if it’s indeed necessary just because I don’t wanna use tor?

And yes, sdwdate isn’t necessary for me(AFAIK) because I use clear net, so it removed this too.

I need a certain clarification on this matter please.

item.title: Cli morphing changed?
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
brilliantjeana:

is kicksecure-qubes-server required after the installation is done?

It is. In Kicksecure 18, that is the primary metapackage for CLI installations of Kicksecure on Qubes OS. If it isn’t installed, future software updates may be incomplete.

brilliantjeana:

and after completion - sudo apt purge tor -y

You probably shouldn’t do this. Tor is preinstalled so that sdwdate-gui will work. This is necessary to get a securely synced system clock, which is useful to ensure things like SSL work correctly.

brilliantjeana:

and it deleted the kicksecure-qubes-server

Yes, this is intended behavior. If you remove a package Kicksecure depends on, the metapackage will go away. If there is a package that is truly superfluous, you can use dummy-dependency to remove it, but in many instances packages that are depended upon (either directly or indirectly) by a metapackage like kicksecure-qubes-server are there for a reason and shouldn’t be removed.

item.title: Cli morphing changed?
item.dc:creator: @brilliantjeana
item.description:
Hi

is kicksecure-qubes-server required after the installation is done?
I used sudo apt install --no-install-recommends kicksecure-qubes-server and after completion - sudo apt purge tor -y and it deleted the kicksecure-qubes-server

please clarify. I don’t recall the same behavior with clipackage on prev version

item.dc:creator: @leok
item.description:
Just a quick question - how often are the ISO’s for “testers” updated?

Plan on doing some intensive testing and would be helpful to know.

item.title: Running Android Apps inside Kicksecure - Waydroid
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
This might work better non in version 18 because port to Wayland has been completed. Note:

  • non-Qubes only
  • Qubes version: No changes. Depends on upstream Qubes implementing Use Wayland instead of X11 to increase performance and improve security · Issue #3366 · QubesOS/qubes-issues · GitHub.

item.title: Rename kicksecure-xfce-installer-cli whonix-xfce-installer-cli in Kicksecure 18
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description: Indeed. This was done.

item.title: Sdwdate broken after upgrade to Kicksecure 18: Missing SECCOMP syscalls (statx, fstatfs, epoll_pwait2)
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
oblivion_devourer:

My architecture is x86_64, I already mentioned that on my original post.

you’re right, my apologies, I missed that.

All my machines are Intel-based. I haven’t seen the issue there, but I do know that differences in CPU architectures can cause issues like this, and I note you’re using an AMD machine, so… maybe that’s the issue? In any event, we’ll likely add those syscalls to the filter. Thank you for reporting this!

item.title: Sdwdate broken after upgrade to Kicksecure 18: Missing SECCOMP syscalls (statx, fstatfs, epoll_pwait2)
item.dc:creator: @oblivion_devourer
item.description:
My architecture is x86_64, I already mentioned that on my original post. I am attaching though the entire output of the lscpu just in case it’s proven useful.

Architecture:                x86_64

  Address sizes:             48 bits physical, 48 bits virtual
  Byte Order:                Little Endian
CPU(s):                      24

Vendor ID:                   AuthenticAMD
  Model name:                AMD Ryzen 9 7900 12-Core Processor
    CPU family:              25

    CPU(s) scaling MHz:      64%
    CPU max MHz:             5482.0000
    CPU min MHz:             545.0000
    BogoMIPS:                7400.26

                             scall nx mmxext fxsr_opt pdpe1gb rdtscp lm constant_tsc rep_good amd_lbr_v2 nopl xtopology nonstop_tsc 
                             cpuid extd_apicid aperfmperf rapl pni pclmulqdq monitor ssse3 fma cx16 sse4_1 sse4_2 movbe popcnt aes x
                             save avx f16c rdrand lahf_lm cmp_legacy svm extapic cr8_legacy abm sse4a misalignsse 3dnowprefetch osvw
                              ibs skinit wdt tce topoext perfctr_core perfctr_nb bpext perfctr_llc mwaitx cpb cat_l3 cdp_l3 hw_pstat
                             e pti ssbd mba perfmon_v2 ibrs ibpb stibp ibrs_enhanced vmmcall fsgsbase bmi1 avx2 smep bmi2 erms invpc

                             2vl xsaveopt xsavec xgetbv1 xsaves cqm_llc cqm_occup_llc cqm_mbm_total cqm_mbm_local user_shstk avx512_
                             bf16 clzero irperf xsaveerptr rdpru wbnoinvd cppc arat npt lbrv svm_lock nrip_save tsc_scale vmcb_clean
                              flushbyasid decodeassists pausefilter pfthreshold avic vgif x2avic v_spec_ctrl vnmi avx512vbmi umip pk
                             u ospke avx512_vbmi2 gfni vaes vpclmulqdq avx512_vnni avx512_bitalg avx512_vpopcntdq rdpid overflow_rec
                             ov succor smca fsrm flush_l1d amd_lbr_pmc_freeze

Caches (sum of all):

  L1i:                       384 KiB (12 instances)
  L2:                        12 MiB (12 instances)
  L3:                        64 MiB (2 instances)
NUMA:                        
  NUMA node(s):              1
  NUMA node0 CPU(s):         0-23
Vulnerabilities:

  Indirect target selection: Mitigation; Aligned branch/return thunks
  Itlb multihit:             Not affected
  L1tf:                      Not affected

  Meltdown:                  Not affected

I should probably point out that I have enabled SMT by editing the /etc/default/grub.d/40_cpu_mitigations.cfg following the instructions in the comments. I haven’t touched the rest of the CPU mitigations, I just didn’t want half of my CPU threads to be disabled.

To be clear though, the issue with sdwdate appeared immediately after the first reboot after the upgrade to 18, before I made any configuration changes.

item.title: Sdwdate broken after upgrade to Kicksecure 18: Missing SECCOMP syscalls (statx, fstatfs, epoll_pwait2)
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
The main thing I’d be interested in knowing is what CPU architecture you’re using. This should show it:

lscpu | grep Architecture

item.title: Can't open proton VPN in kicksecure 18
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
monero-secure:

I am using the Qubes Settings menu for the sys-vpn I have (which I run
the NetworkManager’s built-in VPN support), and in the Firewall
settings, I only allow the vpn server’s IP address to be connected. I
believe this should act as a “kill switch”, in the sense that VPN
server’s IPv4 is the only outgoing address the sys-vpn can connect to.

That’s really clever, thanks for sharing that!

item.title: Can't open proton VPN in kicksecure 18
item.dc:creator: @marcos-morar43
item.description:
Proton VPN is now working in Unrestricted mode.

I reinstalled the user-sysmaint-split package because I was not convinced that, when unrestricted mode is available, there is any need to uninstall this package.

After reinstalling, the first time I started sys-vpn in unrestricted mode, but the proton vpn didn’t work. However, after restarting the qube, it worked on the second attempt.

Through further observation, I discovered that if an app requiring privileged access is started before the user-sysmaint-split removal process completes on each AppVM startup, it will not work, no matter how long you wait afterward.

But if you wait a short while after startup (allowing the system to uninstall user-sysmaint-split in the background) and then start the app, it works.

item.title: Can't open proton VPN in kicksecure 18
item.dc:creator: @monero-secure
item.description:
• Alternatively, you may be able to use NetworkManager’s built-in VPN
    support instead of the app (this won’t come with the kill switch
    though)

I am using this way of using protonvpn. No sudo needed.

this won’t come with the kill switch though

I am using the Qubes Settings menu for the sys-vpn I have (which I run
the NetworkManager’s built-in VPN support), and in the Firewall
settings, I only allow the vpn server’s IP address to be connected. I
believe this should act as a “kill switch”, in the sense that VPN
server’s IPv4 is the only outgoing address the sys-vpn can connect to.

item.title: Can't open proton VPN in kicksecure 18
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
When you boot into unrestricted admin mode, a service starts in the background that uninstalls user-sysmaint-split (though this will only last for one boot of the AppVM because most changes to AppVMs are ephemeral). This takes some time, so if you try to do something that requires administrative permissions immediately after booting into unrestricted admin mode, it probably won’t work. After a few seconds, it should work though.

As for why this broke in Kicksecure 18, I’m not sure either. Nothing new changed about how tight the restrictions are in Kicksecure, so as long as something doesn’t need administrative permissions, things should work. Maybe a setting that didn’t require administrative permissions in Debian 12 now does require administrative permissions in Debian 13.

item.title: Can't open proton VPN in kicksecure 18
item.dc:creator: @marcos-morar43
item.description:
I tried unrestricted mode, but the app didn’t start, though the error was different that time. Then I switched to sysmaint mode, the app launched, the VPN connected successfully, but it wasn’t providing internet to other qubes. Ultimately, removing the user-sysmaint-split worked.

I don’t understand the logic behind it, though. Kicksecure-17 also had the user-sysmaint-split, but it never caused an issue for sys-vpn there. In Kicksecure-18, however, it does, even though the option to use sysmaint or unrestricted mode is now available even for AppVMs, which wasn’t possible before.

That’s really odd!

item.title: Can't open proton VPN in kicksecure 18
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
I’m guessing whatever network setting its trying to set, requires administrative privileges to set, and the fact that pkexec and Polkit prompts are disabled in non-sysmaint sessions is interfering with things. You could try:

  • Booting into “UNRESTRICTED Mode” in the AppVM (you can set this in the settings for the AppVM, under the Advanced tab)
  • Removing user-sysmaint-split from the template, instructions for doing so are here:
Kicksecure – 16 Dec 25

Unrestricted Admin Mode

Kicksecure allows configuration for unrestricted admin mode, enabling the default user account to access privilege escalation tools like sudo and pkexec.

  • Alternatively, you may be able to use NetworkManager’s built-in VPN support instead of the app (this won’t come with the kill switch though)

item.title: Can't open proton VPN in kicksecure 18
item.dc:creator: @marcos-morar43
item.description:
In QubesOS 4.2.4 I’d sys-vpn based on kicksecure-17 and it was working fine.

But in QubesOS 4.3 I am trying to open Proton VPN on kicksecure-18. Initially it opened and worked fine but when I enabled kill switch, now its not opening and giving this error:

2025-12-23T13:25:10.486891+00:00 | proton.vpn.core.connection:508 | INFO | CONN:STATE_CHANGED | Disconnected (initial state)

    await self.context.kill_switch.enable(permanent=True)
  File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/proton/vpn/backend/networkmanager/killswitch/wireguard/wgkillswitch.py", line 64, in enable

        self.nm_client.add_connection_async(kill_switch.connection, save_to_disk=permanent)
    )
  File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/proton/vpn/backend/networkmanager/killswitch/wireguard/killswitch_connection_handler.py", line 56, in _wrap_future                                                     
    return await asyncio.wait_for(
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
    ...<2 lines>...
    )
    ^
  File "/usr/lib/python3.13/asyncio/tasks.py", line 507, in wait_for
    return await fut
           ^^^^^^^^^
  File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/proton/vpn/backend/networkmanager/killswitch/wireguard/nmclient.py", line 185, in _on_connection_added                                                                 
    nm_client.add_connection_finish(res)
    ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~^^^^^
RuntimeError: Error adding KS connection: nm-settings-error-quark: Insufficient privileges (1)
zsh: exit 1     protonvpn-app

Is there a workaround?

xfce -> lxqt

committed 03:11PM - 12 Dec 25 UTC
adrelanos
+31 -31

item.title: Sdwdate broken after upgrade to Kicksecure 18: Missing SECCOMP syscalls (statx, fstatfs, epoll_pwait2)
item.dc:creator: @oblivion_devourer
item.description:
arraybolt3:

Are you using this on baremetal or in a virtual machine?

It’s on baremetal.

arraybolt3:

Could you share some details of your hardware or hypervisor if possible?

Certainly, just tell me what you want to know. Do you need the output of any particular commands?

item.title: Research into Wiping video RAM (VRAM) on shutdown
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
arraybolt3:

init_on_alloc=1 and init_on_free=1 (both of which are set in security-misc-shared).

Right.

init_on_alloc=1 and init_on_free=1 are also set in ram-wipe by default to make it standalone and independent of security-misc.

Related source code file: ram-wipe/etc/default/grub.d/40_ram-wipe.cfg at master · Kicksecure/ram-wipe · GitHub

item.title: Sdwdate broken after upgrade to Kicksecure 18: Missing SECCOMP syscalls (statx, fstatfs, epoll_pwait2)
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
Odd that we didn’t run into this during development. Are you using this on baremetal or in a virtual machine? Could you share some details of your hardware or hypervisor if possible? That might help us reproduce the issue.

(All three of those system calls sound pretty benign, so we can probably add them to the filter even if we can’t reproduce this.)

item.title: When’s kicksecure getting into QubesOS 4.3 templates?
item.dc:creator: @monero-secure
item.description:
• Patrick Kicksecure developer
    December 22

qvm-template --enablerepo qubes-templates-community list

Or enabling qubes-templates-community repository in dom0 by default
required.

I think I already have qubes-templates-community repository in dom0
enabled:

qubes-templates-community  Qubes Community Templates repository  enabled
qubes-templates-itl        Qubes Templates repository            enabled

Yet, cannot see kicksecure-18 template in qvm-template list command
output.

OH, wait, JUST NOW, they appeared:

Installed Templates
debian-13-xfce  0:4.3.0-202512040043  @commandline

item.title: When’s kicksecure getting into QubesOS 4.3 templates?
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
qvm-template --enablerepo qubes-templates-community list

Or enabling qubes-templates-community repository in dom0 by default required.

item.title: Sdwdate broken after upgrade to Kicksecure 18: Missing SECCOMP syscalls (statx, fstatfs, epoll_pwait2)
item.dc:creator: @oblivion_devourer
item.description:
Hello everyone!

After upgrading from Kicksecure 17 to 18 I noticed that sdwdate never finished syncing time. After checking the logs I found several lines similar to this,

SECCOMP auid=4294967295 uid=117 gid=130 ses=4294967295 subj=unconfined pid=6319 comm=“leaprun” exe=“/usr/bin/python3.13” sig=31 arch=c000003e syscall=332 compat=0 ip=0x7c87efbaf31a code=0x80000000

By following the instructions on Debugging Systemd Seccomp, I figure out that syscalls 332 (statx), 138 (fstatfs) and 441 (epoll_pwait2) needed to be added to SystemCallFilter=. And indeed after doing that the issue was completely fixed. Architecture is x86_64.

Sorry if this is not the correct category, I wasn’t sure if I should post this on Support or Development.

item.title: Kicksecure 18 Released! Major Release Upgrade!

item.title: When’s kicksecure getting into QubesOS 4.3 templates?
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
By the time you posted that, the Template was only in qubes-templates-community-testing, Hence, command line parameter --enablerepo qubes-templates-community-testing would be needed.

qvm-template --enablerepo qubes-templates-community-testing list

In any case, Kicksecure could be installed as per installation documentation: Kicksecure for Qubes

The Template is now in the qubes-templates-community so the issue should be no longer occurring in any case.

item.title: Kicksecure 18 Released! Major Release Upgrade!
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
The most important is probably installing, booting, boot modes, persistence, upgrading, systemcheck. If any of that is broken (except systemcheck), that would be pretty bad. For example, if upgrading was broken, then smaller bugs could not be fixed through upgrades.

Try your personal use cases. If you that that, then that’s already super helpful and a lot.

Here’s our official plan for now:

Kicksecure – 22 Dec 25

Kicksecure How to test an OS

Testing OS installation and Post Installation

item.title: Research into Wiping video RAM (VRAM) on shutdown
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
There are a lot of questions here; generally it’s better to have one forum post per question to keep things easy to track. (We use posts, especially development posts, to track individual things that need worked on, so keeping one topic per post makes us able to do that.)

Tengu:

When the system powers down, the kernel stops the CPUs and tells each driver to simply hand the device back to the firmware. The firmware may or may not clear the memory when power is removed. Complete loss of power guarantees erasure usually right?

It’s supposed to, and in practice it usually does. Unfortunately, it doesn’t always do so, 3mdeb did some research on how different RAM responds to power loss and some of it can maintain a substantial amount of data for alarmingly long. (One particular 4GB DDR4 DIMM from Kingston ended up retaining a tiny, but recognizable, amount of data for two minutes after power loss. Most other memory tested didn’t do that, but it’s dependent on the particular RAM you have.) See:

blog.3mdeb.com

Thoughts dereferenced from the scratchpad noise. | Research of RAM data...

blog.3mdeb.com

Thoughts dereferenced from the scratchpad noise. | Research of RAM data...

blog.3mdeb.com

Thoughts dereferenced from the scratchpad noise. | Conclusions from RAM data...

Many systems (all of them except for those with discrete GPUs) have video and system memory on the same RAM modules, so turning off the GPU first probably wouldn’t help much. What would help is the ability to wipe RAM when it’s no longer used, which we try to do via the kernel parameters init_on_alloc=1 and init_on_free=1 (both of which are set in security-misc-shared). It’s unclear if the Intel and AMD graphics subsystems actually obey these kernel parameters though; if the GPU reserves memory entirely for its own use, it might be out of the kernel’s control. Systems with discrete GPUs are even less likely to obey those settings.

We have a task made to look at wiping VRAM (ToDo for Developers), but it’s pretty low in the priority list.

item.title: For how long would it be safe to use 17.4.4.6?
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
Banebere:

The question goes for whonix 17 also, but to put it mildly 18 needs a bit of polishing,

Are there specific things that need polishing (beyond the one mentioned here)? From our standpoint Kicksecure 18 is stable, and while we are still polishing some things to make them more user-friendly, it’s very possible we’ll miss things if they aren’t pointed out. (Everyone’s use case is different, so we’re naturally more likely to notice issues that impact our workflows, and we don’t have telemetry to tell us what other people’s workflows are.)

Banebere:

the main thing is that i need copy paste and with the wayland bug on virtualbox I aint getting that.

Yeah, that is a problem. We’re somewhat at the mercy of Oracle here, once they fix it things should work, but until then we’re sort of stuck in a bind. (KVM is busted in a similar way, no working Wayland support in spice-vdagent.) Shared folders can be used as a workaround.

Banebere:

So the question is for how long will the 17.4.4.6 versions of whonix and kick be safe to use?

Usually previous major versions of Kicksecure are considered end-of-life pretty shortly after new major version are released. Because of Qubes OS considerations, we’ll probably support version 17 for another couple of months or so, but I wouldn’t expect it to be much longer than that.

item.title: Extrepo doesn't include Trixie
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description: Debian Salsa is Debian’s official Git forge, and it is a Gitlab instance. While I don’t know for certain if that specific extrepo repository is the official one upstream, I wouldn’t be surprised if it was, and extrepo is part of Debian. Our documentation recommends using it in some areas, so it would be good if it were kept up-to-date. I may be able to get the time to submit a fix upstream to re-enable the Trixie repo now that we have one.

item.title: Switch LXQT compositor/labwc settings?
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
zaliv:

That said, given this is LXQT, is there a way to access the settings of labwc

I don’t think a GUI for this is pre-installed in Kicksecure. There is labwc-tweaks, but unfortunately that isn’t present in Debian Trixie (which Kicksecure 18 is based on), and it doesn’t have signed releases so we were reticent to package it ourselves. Currently the best way to tweak labwc settings is to read labwc’s documentation and place your customizations in ~/.config/labwc/rc.xml or another appropriate configuration file. (Note that we have layered configuration enabled in labwc, so you should only have to set the settings you want to change; anything that isn’t explicitly specified will fall back to system-wide configuration.)

zaliv:

and/or change the compositor to Sway (for tiling)?

We don’t explicitly support switching to Sway, and because of how our Wayland session works it might be difficult to do so. /usr/libexec/desktop-config-dist/start-lxqt-session should give you a good starting point to work from, but keep in mind changes made to this file will be overwritten by upgrades of desktop-config-dist so modifying it directly is not recommended.

zaliv:

I couldn’t see any GUI settings for this, but I was pretty sure they existed (granted it has been a while since I last used LXQT).

They exist under X11. Unfortunately a lot of the GUI configuration tools in LXQt 2.1 are disabled when using Wayland, and some of the tools will likely remain that way permanently because LXQt doesn’t want to add compositor-specific code if possible. Tools like labwc-tweaks are supposed to fill in the gaps there, and we also have been creating some of our own tools (like set-labwc-keymap and set-system-keymap) to fill in more of the gaps.

zaliv:

Is there any way to change these safely?

Modifying user-specific configuration files like mentioned above is probably the best way forward.

item.title: Unplugging external drive should trigger a shutdown
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description: Assuming it works at all, it will almost certainly work with the panic keyboard shortcut. Unsure if it will work with drive unplug, feel free to try it.

item.title: Grub Live vs toram?
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
Tengu:

Is rd.live.ram= depreciated or changed? What branch is dracut sourced from? Is it from testing I’d assume right?

Not that I’m aware of. Kicksecure doesn’t use it in our packages, and I doubt it would work on a fully installed system since it likely wants to copy a live image into RAM, not an installed partition. If you want to try using it with the ISO (or in other contexts), you’re welcome to; the 90dmsquash-live module in Kicksecure’s version of dracut seems to have the ability to parse rd.live.ram, so I assume it’s supported.

Kicksecure is using the same version of Dracut that’s in Debian Trixie. Right now that’s version 106-6 (so upstream version 106, Debian revision 6). We’ll probably stick with that for the duration of Kicksecure 18’s support.

Tengu:

Has Kicksecure fully transitioned to dracut as its initramfs generator?

We have indeed. We were using it as our primary initramfs generator in Kicksecure 17, but had initramfs-tools support as a fallback. In Kicksecure 18 we dropped the initramfs-tools support and are relying solely on Dracut.

Tengu:

Is Kicksecure the first debian based distro that uses dracut?

Not sure. We’ve been using it longer than Ubuntu, but not sure if we’re the first. It works for us and our users, that’s what we care about mainly.

item.title: Research into Wiping video RAM (VRAM) on shutdown
item.dc:creator: @Tengu
item.description: cat /sys/class/drm/card*/device/power_state returns D0 or D3cold indicating the power state
